text: On a complete aside, in my opinion, being a lisp is moreso a philosophy then a set of features a language has.

elements.text: On a complete aside, in my opinion, being a lisp is moreso a philosophy then a set of features a language has.

text: I’d disagree. A lot has to do with being able to treat a program as data. In the parsed AST form, Julia really does seem like a type of Lisp. (Gerry Sussman, of Scheme fame, seemed to agree with that, but he complained that he really didn’t want the extra layer of syntactic sugar layered on top, he just wanted to program using the s-exprs *directly* :nerd_face:)
